>So said Jason Rogers on 2003-06-13 --------------------
>On Fri, 13 Jun 20=
03 16:54:16 -0700, "Eric Armstrong"
><eric.armstrong@...> said:
>[snip]=

>> There is no "get" in this system, but the test can still verify
>> that=
 the internal state is as expected, using state-verification
>> methods int=
ended for that purpose.
>
>Interesting points.  My general take on the matt=
er is that there is no
>one answer.  I think the system itself will dictate=
 the best approach. 
>One thing that I do feel very strongly about is that =
a plethora or
>getters/setters tends to indicate that the object design is =
faulty.  

I disagree. Model objects representing values should be transpar=
ent, a la "Naked Objects". They should let the Model objects containing bus=
iness logic "do with them what they may". There is a tendency in OOP to pre=
tend there is behavior where there is no behavior. I think that is a mistak=
e. Some objects in the system are just bags of data. I think public fields =
should do nicely there. Ward Cunningham has been experimenting with ignorin=
g the prevaling paranoia against public data. I haven't seen him write anyt=
hing on it yet, but it's good to test long-standing "rules".

> I
>think th=
at goes more for the setters than the getters.  It's my
>contention, and I =
code this way every day of the week, that an object
>should be instantiated=
 in a sane state.  You should not need to 'new' an
>object and then turn ri=
ght back around a call 1..N setter methods on it.

Indeed!

One counterexam=
ple is an object with 20 fields. Perhaps 20 set methods is clearer, at leas=
t in a language like Java with positional parameters. (In Smalltalk it's ex=
actly the same, so it doesn't matter.) Should an object have 20 fields? Per=
haps not, but some do. It is not clear that breaking that 20-field objects =
into four 5-field objects is any better.

<snip />

Take care.


J. B. Rain=
sberger,
